section.name: JDO : Annotations
section.p: One of the things that JDK 1.5 provides that can be of some use is annotations, and JDO provides its own set. When selecting to use annotations please bear in mind the following :-

ul.li: You must have the datanucleus-api-jdo jar available in your CLASSPATH.
You must have the jdo-api jar in your CLASSPATH since this provides the annotations

Annotations should really only be used for attributes of persistence that you won't be changing at deployment. Things such as table and column names shouldn't really be specified using annotations although it is permitted. Instead it would be better to put such information in an ORM MetaData file.
Annotations can be added in two places - for the class as a whole, or for a field in particular.

You can annotate fields or getters with field-level information. If you annotate fields then the fields are processed for persistence. If you annotate the methods (getters) then the methods (properties) are processed for persistence.
Annotations are prefixed by the @ symbol and can take properties (in brackets after the name, comma-separated)

section.p: Annotations supported by DataNucleus are shown below. The annotations/attributes coloured in pink are ORM and really should be placed in XML rather than directly in the class using annotations.

subsection.name: @PersistenceCapable
subsection.p: This annotation is used when you want to mark a class as persistent. It equates to the <class> XML element (though with only some of its attributes). Specified on the class.

tr.td: Whether an extent is required for this class
Whether objects of this class can only be stored embedded in other objects
Whether objects of this class can be detached
ORM : Name of the table where this class is persisted
ORM : Name of the catalog where this table is persisted
ORM : Name of the schema where this table is persisted
Whether the class can be L2 cached. From JDO2.2
Whether to default reads of this object type to lock the object

subsection.name: @PersistenceAware
subsection.p: This annotation is used when you want to mark a class as being used in persistence but not being persistable. That is "persistence-aware" in JDO2 terminology. It has no attributes. Specified on the class.
See the documentation for Class Mapping

subsection.name: @Cacheable
subsection.p: This annotation is a shortcut for @PersistenceCapable(cacheable={value}) specifying whether the class can be cached in a Level 2 cache. Specified on the class. The default
See the documentation for L2 Caching

subsection.name: @EmbeddedOnly
subsection.p: This annotation is a shortcut for @PersistenceCapable(embeddedOnly="true") meaning that the class can only be persisted embedded into another class. It has no attributes. Specified on the class.

subsection.name: @Inheritance
subsection.p: Annotation used to define the inheritance for a class. Specified on the class.

tr.td: Name of a custom inheritance strategy (DataNucleus supports "complete-table")

ORM : Name of the column to use to store the discriminator
ORM : Whether the discriminator column is to be indexed
ORM : Column definitions used for storing the discriminator

subsection.p: Annotation used to define the identity when using datastore-identity for the class. Specified on the class.

subsection.name: @Serialized
subsection.p: This annotation is a shortcut for @Persistent(serialized="true") meaning that the field is stored serialized. It has no attributes. Specified on the field/method.
See the documentation for Serialising

subsection.name: @NotPersistent
subsection.p: This annotation is a shortcut for @Persistent(persistenceModifier=PersistenceModifier.NONE) meaning that the field/property is not persisted. It has no attributes. Specified on the field/method.
See the documentation for Fields/Properties

subsection.name: @Transactional
subsection.p: This annotation is a shortcut for @Persistent(persistenceModifier=PersistenceModifier.TRANSACTIONAL) meaning that the field/property is not persisted yet managed. It has no attributes. Specified on the field/method.
